title-group.article-title: יחס חוב תוצר, התחייבויות פנסיוניות ואיתנות פיננסית

trans-title-group.trans-title: The Debt Ratio, Pension Liabilities and Financial Stability

abstract.p: One of the leading indicators of countries' economic stability is the ratio of public debt to GDP. The public debt includes only ordinary debt, whereas most countries also have pension liabilities. There is no significant difference between the ordinary and the implicit debt, except the latter's greater uncertainty. Therefore the public debt should include the implicit debt. Starting in 2017 the EU countries will publish their pension liabilities. Maybe this will cause the international rating companies to include the implicit debt. According to data presented in the article, this might cause a major change both in the absolute size of the debt and in the relative ranking of various countries. The calculation of implicit debt burdens are complicated and very sensitive to interest rates, longevity etc. Therefore international methodologies will have to be introduced. The two debt types are taxed differently and therefore, in an after-tax analysis, their relative burdens are different.
